content.description: Very fun, short & powerful route with many hidden pockets and slopers.  Very sustained until you touch the chains.  Climbs the left part of the pillar, starts about 10 feet right of the over hang problem. This route had tattered webbing and a single bolt at the top which I replaced with heavy duty chains and added a ring anchor.  This would be 4 stars if it were longer, best route I've found yet at West Nephi.
content.location: Right next to the start of the over hang boulder, there is a pillar with two top rope anchors approximately 35 feet tall.  Anchors are newly placed rappel ring and chain.  Scramble to the top of the boulder to set the top rope.

content.description: obvious boulder across from the highball, not too far from the overhang boulder. There are several problems on this boulder. There is an obvious v0/1ish crack in the center that distinguishes this boulder in an area with many. Locals feel free to chime in?
content.location: among the many boulders lies this fun guy

content.description: This little sit start has some pretty tuff first moves. You start in two little pockets and then move into a decent pinch. Pump up to some crimbers, then you’ve gotten past the hard stuff after that it’s just finding the right holds to get you to a solid jug just before the top out. It definitely climbs for all shapes and sizes and is a short little boulder. No high balling here.
content.protection: The climb is pretty easy to bail off of and crash pad isn’t necessary.
content.location: We found the climb because there was two chalk hands slapped in front of it. If you get up to the boulders there are two alley’s almost. The second alley has the “huge boulder” right in the middle of it. The first alley has “Melanie’s high ball” and the “tombstone” there is a very obvious tall V-1 on the otherside of the alley from Melanie’s high ball. This climb is around the left on a ledge.

content.description: It has a good standing start that leads to a couple of solid pockets. Reach left to some good holds on an arête get some high feet and get to the first ledge then Traverse right to top out. I didn’t try to go up to the second ledge because it is a bit sketchy to go up and I didn’t have the guts, but It’s a very clean route (which makes me think it’s been done before but I just want more people to try it, so if you want to lay claim to this route please do and I’ll update the info) great route for beginners and people who like pockets, if you’re weird like that.
content.protection: Two crash pads are suggested because there are two levels at the bottom that split the route.
content.location: When you get to the parking area you will see a stripe of beautiful red granite boulders. If you go back the road a little ways across the street from the parking area you will see two metal portions in the fence that look a lot like gates, they are not, but if you hop the fence at the second gate (it is really the third gate but the first one is right across from the parking area. If you haven’t past the tagged rock that says Tyler on it three times you haven’t gone far enough.) hop the fence there and continue up the hill at an angle toward the east end of the strip of boulders. You will see a tall boulder on the far left that has a head on it. On the east side of the boulder you will see some cracks and the route is on the left side of the wall.

content.description: The crux is at the sit start. It is very sedimetary rock, i.e. it is quartzite crystals all glued together but chossy. Fun tricky sloper of the start, pretty cool.

content.description:
Sit start laid back to the right with left hand in low hueco and right hand on a crimp.  Crank up to huecos closely placed above the starting hueco until you can pull your feet underneath you.  Finish on easy slab.

I'm not sure if the route has already been sent, but I'm putting it up since there's no info on it on MP.  If there's already a name and an FA for it, let me know.
content.location: This is on the slab face of the Ramp Boulder that is opposite to Jsmith and The Ramp.

content.description: This one is the second set of anchors on the pillar containing the route oil filter.  Start just left of the arete on a series of pockets.  One of the deep mono pockets contained a very anrgy bat of which my wife accidentally disturbed when attempting to use the pocket.  This route had tattered webbing and a single bolt at the top which we replaced with heavy duty chains and added a ring anchor.  Very fun!
